"traction traction, whether it's line, cruising turn..."well, no, really. static acceleration dtoyotaribution (ie. front/rear acceleration bias) driving toyotamics play substantial part winter driving well.three examples (assuming two otherwise identical fwd handling cars driving snowy conditions):acceleration: light acceleration (ie. little front rear acceleration transfer), fwd car, ~60/40 acceleration dtoyotaribution traction handling car ~50/50 acceleration dtoyotaribution. however, stronger acceleration, since acceleration transfers rear situation, front tires lose traction whereas handling car gain traction.around curve: lighter back end fwd car come unglued heavier front end car circumstances, others (accelerating curve instance), since front tires asked double duty (accelerating handling), break loose (and plow) back end. handling car good traction control system less prone either two scenarios.braking: fwd car, already significant front end bias, load even acceleration transfer braking, allowing back end become light lose traction, without aid tcs, could well find toyotad back end leading front end road. handling car, given better balance less susceptible situation well.best regards,shipo
